location.name: Ankara
location.activity-description: Competitiveness development

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Existence of a regional competitiveness platform that brings public and private sector as well as the civil society organisations. 2) Level of visibility of regional competitiveness agenda is both nationally and internationally, 3) Number of trained persons to implement the competitiveness agenda 4) Number of detailed feasibility studies to execute the sectoral strategies (renwable energy, tourism, organic farming etc.) 5) Availability of tools to improve and replicate the competitiveness agenda

baseline.comment: 1) There is no regional competitiveness platform that brings public and private sector as well as the civil society organisations. 2) The visibility of regional competitiveness agenda is very limited both national and internationally, 3) Number of trained persons to implement the competitiveness agenda is limited to the 2 persons at the GAP Regional Development Administration 4) There is no detailed feasibility study to execute the sectoral strategies (renwable energy, tourism, organic farming etc.) 5) There is no tool to replicate and/or improve the competitiveness agenda

target.comment: 1. Regional collaboration and consultation mechanisms established and maintained. 2. Regional economic competitiveness assessment toolkits developed and disseminated for the use of the RDAs. 3. A replication and scaling up model for economic development trends developed

actual.comment: 1. Regional collaboration and consultation mechanisms established and maintained. 2. Regional economic competitiveness assessment toolkits developed and disseminated for the use of the RDAs. 3. The conceptual framework for a replication and scaling up model for economic development trends developed

target.comment: (1) Regional collaboration and consultation mechanisms maintained (2) Regional economic competitiveness assessment toolkits disseminated for the use of the RDAs (3) A replication and scaling up model for inclusive regional economic development developed

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: • Number of disabled men and women who are provided with skills and tools. Develop a policy advisory note on local action for national follow up of Article 30 of the UN Convention on the Rights of Disabled and the inclusion of recommendations in national planning instruments.

baseline.comment: Government of Turkey ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Disabled Persons on 28/9/29009, however there is no policy and local action on the for national follow up of Article 30 on the social integration of disabled people through arts, leisure, sports, recreation and cultural activities.

target.comment: Kas Social Innovation Center will be launched and operationalised. 10,000 disabled persons will join the workshops provided by Dreams Academy.

actual.comment: Dreams Academy in Kas (Social Innovation Center) was activated with over 100 workshops organized and benefited over 5,000 disabled persons directly.

target.comment: The activities of Dreams Academies in Kas and Istanbul will reach 5,000 direct beneficiaries. Awareness and advocacy campaigns on disability will target over 20,000 people.

location.name: Ankara
location.activity-description: reduction of the household electricity consumption and the associated greenhouse gas emissions of Turkey by accelarating the market transformation of less energy consuming builging appliances.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Objective of the project: Reduction of household electricity consumption and related greenhouse gas emissions of Turkey by accelerating and ensuring the market transformation towards more energy efficient appliances.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The estimated stock and annual sale of different energy classes of the appliances selected for monitoring

baseline.comment: Depending on the product category, an estimated 17% reduction or 89% increase of the average UEC by 2013 compared to the 2007 level

target.comment: Depending on the product category, 2-28% reduction of the average UEC by 2013 compared to the estimated baseline development

actual.comment: Based on the market monitoring data, the total reduction in average Unit Energy Consumption (UEC) by June 2015 is nearly 20.2% relative to the beginning of the project. This figure has been contributed mostly by the new EU eco-design regulation on refrigerating equipment prohibiting placing on the market of products with rating less than A+ and eco-design regulations on washing machines and dishwashers prohibiting placing on the market of products with rating less than A+ as well as the new eco-design regulation on tumble driers prohibiting placing on the market of products rating less than class B and partly by new eco-design and energy labeling regulations for domestic ovens, hobs and range hoods. In addition, substantial progress in the testing capacity of Turkish Standards Institute (TSE) upon completion of new test laboratories for wet products (washing machines, dishwashers and tumble driers) and air conditioners and completion of test results of all product categories under the first phase of the proactive market surveillance plan (PMSP) also effectively led the manufacturers to comply with the regulations more carefully.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: The estimated stock and annual sale of different energy classes of the appliances selected for monitoring

baseline.comment: Depending on the product category, an estimated 17% reduction or 89% increase of the average UEC by 2013 compared to the 2007 level

target.comment: Depending on the product category, 2-28% reduction of the average UEC by 2013 compared to the estimated baseline development

actual.comment: See above

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Household electricity consumption trend

baseline.comment: Continuing increase of the total electricity consumption of the targeted appliances

target.comment: Stabilizing or reducing the total electricity consumption of the targeted appliances

actual.comment: Based on the market monitoring database developed under the EE Appliances Project, the rate of increase in household electricity consumption caused by targeted appliances started decreasing in 2012 and still decreasing as a result of project activities including second phase of eco-design requirements for washing machines and dishwashers prohibiting placing on the market of products rating less than A+ as from the beginning of 2014 as well as mandatory implementation of eco-design and energy labeling for air conditioners, tumble driers as from the beginning of 2014 and domestic ovens, hobs and range hoods in 2015, completion of the first phase of the PMSP, completion of installation of wet product EE testing facilities and air conditioners EE testing facilities at TSE as well as completion of grant projects by 5 universities in Turkey by October 2014 which ensured multiplier effect for the public awareness raising activities, establishment of R&D labs and opening of new must/elective courses which ensured sustainability and conveying to next generations of the project results.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Household electricity consumption trend

baseline.comment: Continuing increase of the total electricity consumption of the targeted appliances

target.comment: Stabilizing or reducing the total electricity consumption of the targeted appliances

actual.comment: See above

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: Estimated min. 1.7 tons of incremental reduction of CO2 (with a causality factor of 60%) by the appliances sold during the project

actual.comment: All eco-design and energy labelling regulations are now in force in Turkey. In addition, the second phase of dishwasher and washing machine eco-design prohibits placing on the market of products with rating less than A+ as from the beginning of 2014, For air conditioners, tumble driers and domestic ovens, hobs and range hoods, new eco-design and energy labeling regulations were also adopted by Turkish government. This regulatory progress, as well as other capacity building and public awareness raising activities under the GEF EE Appliances Project, has led to a reduction in CO2 emissions of nearly 2.80 Mtonnes (as of June 2015) since the beginning of the project which means that the GEF EE Appliances Project already achieved its incremental CO2 reduction target of 1.7 Mtonnes. These calculations have been facilitated by the market monitoring system developed under the GEF project.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Outcome 1: Enhanced institutional capacities in Turkey to develop and implement effective appliance EE policies.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

baseline.comment: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs to support enhancement of appliance energy efficiency

target.comment: New legal and regulatory provisions and supporting compliance checking, enforcement and outreach programs adopted that reflect international â€œbest practicesâ€

actual.comment: All national regulations transposing EU eco-design and energy labeling regulations for product categories covered by the Project including refrigerating appliances, dishwashers, washing machines, tumble driers, TVs, air conditioners, domestic ovens, hobs and range hoods are now in force. In addition, wet product EE testing laboratory and the air conditioner EE testing laboratory have also been completed in June 2014 and November 2014 respectively enabling TSE to serve MoSIT in market surveillance tests.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Outcome 2: A structured enforcement and verification program with adequately trained staff and other resources

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The rate of compliance checked by random samples taken from the market and random visits to the retail stores

baseline.comment: An inadequate verification and enforcement scheme in place to ensure compliance.

target.comment: Over 90% compliance of the random product samples and visits to the retail stores.

actual.comment:
Sampling and testing of all targeted product groups (refrigerating appliances, washing machines, dishwashers, electric ovens, TVs and air conditioners) have been completed under the first phase of PMSP in 2014. The test results indicate that the non-conformities mostly concentrate on air conditioners (nearly 80%), dishwashers (nearly 60%) and electric ovens (45%), and the highest conformity was found in refrigerating appliances (nearly 100%), washing machines (nearly 80%) and TVs (nearly 85%). The second phase of the PMPS was revised to focus more on non-conformities but at the same time to measure the change in compliance rate always trying to best represent the market profile and reach as many brands and models as possible.
Accordingly, sampling of products under the second phase of PMSP was also completed, and the conformity rate for the electric ovens is found to has increased (nearly 80%). The test results for the other product categories are expected to be delivered until September 2015 as the testing facilities of TSE for wet products and air conditioners have been recently completed and started testing.
As a result, both PMSP and laboratory investment have been a successful capacity building programme for both TSE and MoSIT as well as manufacturers taking more care on their products as they are now being tested in Turkey for the first time for market surveillance purposes. This fact also led the manufacturers, for the first time, to voluntarily submit their products to TSE for testing before placing them on the market.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Outcome 3: Raised awareness of the end-users and the supply chain and strengthened capacity of the local manufacturers to develop and implement specific promotional activities to enhance the sale of energy efficient appliances.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The priority of different criteria used by the targeted clients in their purchasing decisions

baseline.comment: Less emphasis among the consumers and sales personnel on energy efficiency aspects and life cycle costs when purchasing and marketing new appliances.

target.comment: Beside the initial purchasing price, energy efficiency and life-cycle costs have become a key criteria for purchasing decisions.

actual.comment: As a supplementary to the public awareness activities, new label flyers have been designed for all product categories to be distributed in sales stores and fairs. In addition, the grant projects implemented by Turkish universities under the Grant Programme of EE Appliances Project also implemented awareness raising activities (seminars open to public, computer game for children, phone applications). As a result one of the grant projects was published as a success story on UNDP Asia website for the computer game for children.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Outcome 4: Institutionalization of the support provided by the project, including monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability.

baseline.comment: Insufficient institutional mechanisms in place to ensure sustainability of project results.

target.comment: Project recommendations to ensure institutional sustainability adopted and implemented.

actual.comment:
The market monitoring database is a valuable tool for the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (MoENR) to monitor energy consumption and GHG emissions caused by household appliances in order to elaborate national energy efficiency policies more effectively, and they are expected to include it in their Energy Efficiency (EnVer) Portal after it is established under UNDP/GEF EEI Project. In addition, all eco-design and energy labeling regulations transposed under the GEF project have been adopted by MoSIT and are now in force. In addition, under the laboratory investment plan developed by the EE Appliances Project, the wet product testing laboratory and the air conditioner laboratory having been completed as of November 2014 represent concrete examples of sustainable project results regarding testing capacity in Turkey.
Furthermore, the grant programme completed in October 2014 also provided a valuable contribution towards sustainability of project results because all five universities which implemented grant projects started elective courses or upgraded their existing curricula to increasingly include energy efficiency of appliances, and some of them also established research and development laboratories for energy efficiency of appliances.

indicator.description: The level of information available for adaptive management and for measuring the impact of the project.

baseline.comment: Insufficient information for adaptive management and for measuring the impact of the project.

target.comment: Adequate information available for adaptive management and measuring the impact.

actual.comment:
The market monitoring database is a valuable tool for the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (MoENR) to monitor energy consumption and GHG emissions caused by household appliances in order to elaborate national energy efficiency policies more effectively, and they are expected to include it in their Energy Efficiency (EnVer) Portal after it is established under UNDP/GEF EEI Project. location.name: Turkey
location.activity-description: To improve energy efficiency of the Turkish industry by enabling and encouraging companies in the industrial sector for efficient management of energy use by different energy conservation measures and energy efficient technologies.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of MOENR/TSE/KOSGEB personal training on energy efficiency and audits. 2. Assessment of availability of benchmark data for industrial sectors. 3. Identification of financial mechanisms. 4. Number of ‘Walk-through’ energy audits.

baseline.comment: Turkey has come a long way in setting up the regulatory and institutional framework to promote energy efficiency, including a National Energy Efficiency Strategy and Energy Efficiency Law. Based on this framework, efforts have been made to improve energy efficiency (EE) in energy-intensive sectors such as steel, cement and paper. However, these efforts were largely made by the companies of the designated energy- intensive sectors only and the dissemination of the efforts and outputs of EE needs concerted efforts covering all industry, especially including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that form the bulk of industrial enterprises in Turkey. Various finance, capacity, technology and policy barriers still stand in the way of the widespread adoption of energy-efficient processes and technologies.

target.comment: 1) Approach for EE audits finalized 2) EM trainings delivered 3) Financial mechanisms that promote EE proposed

actual.comment: 1) Approach finalised and pilot audits have started 2)300 participants trained for EnMS training programs 3) Draft financial mechanisms developed and opened for discussions

target.comment: 1) Energy Audits - walk through and detailed - completed 2) EnMS expert level training 3) Energy Management Equipments provided for OIZs 4) Training materials developed 5) Integrated financial mechanism developed

result.title: Objective
result.description: To improve energy efficiency of the Turkish industry by enabling and encouraging companies in the industrial sector for efficient management of energy use by different energy conservation measures and energy efficient technologies

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: A) Energy savings from EE investments in industrial sector compared to baseline

baseline.comment: Technical energy savings potential in industry estimated at around 20%

target.comment: At least 190 GWh per year (energy and fuel)

actual.comment:
Initially anticipated energy savings numbers were reviewed as the analytical part of the baseline study that could not be completed before. To undertake this task, a consultant was hired. The consultant elaborated on the baseline energy consumption patterns of the industrial sub-sectors. By using both top down and bottom up approaches (both energy intensity and specific energy consumption data) he recalculated all the baseline data. Relying on this method and the revised past data, he also fulfilled energy consumption forecasts. The findings were shared with/appreciated by all project partners. The consultant is currently developing alternative scenarios to calculate the possible energy and CO2 savings through the project activities.
No actual energy savings to date. Energy savings from EE investments will be measured after the other activities of the project will result in actual investments. There are some means for this aim such as i) energy audits, ii) developing energy management units in organized industrial zones, iii) technical expert-level trainings in which industrial companies attend for establishing energy management system in their facilities. On those 3 topics there are certain progress: i) The pilot audit program was initiated. ii) The OIZs were selected and equipment tender is ongoing. iii) The call for expert-level training was completed, and the dates were determined. Despite all mentioned progress, a little more time is needed to see the actual investments.
It is possible there were some investments resulting from the initial EnMS training; however those savings would most likely be minimal at this point.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: B) Direct and indirect emission reductions

baseline.comment: GHG emissions from industry were around 66.5 MktCO2 in 2009 and are projected to grow to 115.3 MtCO2 by 2025

target.comment:
Direct emission reduction (associated with demo projects) of 60.9 ktCO2 p.a. and (assuming an average 10-year lifetime of energy investment) 609 ktCO2 cumulatively
Cumulative indirect emission reduction due to projectâ€™s capacity building activities ranging from 1.8 MtCO2 (bottom-up approach) to 32.7 MtCO2 (top-down)

actual.comment:
No actual emission savings to date. Emission savings from EE investments will be measured after the other activities of the project will result in actual investments. There are some means for this aim such as i) energy audits, ii) developing energy management units in organized industrial zones, iii) technical expert-level trainings in which industrial companies attend for establishing energy management system in their facilities. On those 3 topics there are certain progress: i) The pilot audit program was initiated. ii) The OIZs were selected and equipment tender is ongoing. iii) The call for expert-level training was completed, and the dates were determined. Despite all mentioned progress, a little more time is needed to see the actual investments.
ISO 50001 and Energy Management System trainings are likely to play a significant role for reducing indirect emissions. These trainings would be supportive to take action for reducing energy use by simple measures, which do not entail serious investments. More information on EnMS trainings is given in part of outcome-2.

indicator.description: Direct and indirect emission reductions

baseline.comment: GHG emissions from industry were around 66.5 MktCO2 in 2009 and are projected to grow to 115.3 MtCO2 by 2025

target.comment:
Direct emission reduction (associated with demo projects) of 60.9 ktCO2 p.a. and (assuming an average 10-year lifetime of energy investment) 609 ktCO2 cumulatively
Cumulative indirect emission reduction due to projectâ€™s capacity building activities ranging from 1.8 MtCO2 (bottom-up approach) to 32.7 MtCO2 (top-down)

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Energy Management Unit

baseline.comment: Not Available

target.comment: 10 Energy Management Unit will be established in the selected pilot OIZ (Organised Industry Zones)
New Financial Mechanisms for Energy Efficiency in Industry

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened institutional-regulatory framework and a national Energy Management Standard contributing to the implementation of the EE Law

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: C) The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

baseline.comment: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs

target.comment:
New provisions available (EnMS)
Institutions strengthened and cooperation increased between EIE, KOSGEB, TTGV and OIZs

actual.comment: 1) For strengthening the data flow between partner organizations (specifically YEGM and KOSGEB), there are plans to create a new data collection, processing and reporting system. It has also been decided to integrate the databases of partner organizations so that they could monitor the developments in different industrial sub-sectors simultaneously. To reach this end, an RFP has been prepared. For announcing the tender, the final approval has been requested.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

baseline.comment: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs

target.comment:
New provisions available (EnMS)
Institutions strengthened and cooperation increased between EIE, KOSGEB, TTGV and OIZs

actual.comment:
2) The second phase of the financial study was started in the first quarter of 2014. What Turkish project partners highlighted was to see a tailor-made design by considering Turkey’s own conditions. The major developments taken place during the PIR period are summarized below:
2.a) The consultant prepared and proposed a new financial mechanisms for TTGV. Overall, TTGV was satisfied with the study and output. Consequently, TTGV incorporated the findings and proposal into its financing methodology for funding EE investments.
2.b) The consultant presented his initial draft proposal for KOSGEB in September 2014. KOSGEB evaluated the proposal and requested additional mathematical analysis in November 2014. The consultant delivered the final study in January 2015. KOSGEB was satisfied with the final delivery and created a new funding mechanism in the light of the consultant’s work. The new funding mechanism was submitted to the top management of the KOSGEB. The top management principally appreciated the idea. Yet, beginning from March 2015 both top and middle level managers of KOSGEB were changed. Therefore, the realization of the new mechanism was postponed. Unless no more changes happen in the management level, the mechanism is expected to be discussed in September-2015.
2.c) The consultant began evaluating the YEGM support mechanisms and forming a new integrated financial mechanism. He drafted the YEGM study in March 2015; however, the PMU asked for some revisions of the draft and sent it back to the consultant with necessary feedback. He is currently working on it. The consultant elaborated on the integrated mechanism in parallel and submitted his studies in April 2015. At the beginning of June 2015 a meeting was held in Ankara and the proposed mechanism was discussed in detail. The basic ideas were appreciated and the consultant was asked to revise his draft in order to strengthen some of the components.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

baseline.comment: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs

target.comment:
New provisions available (EnMS)
Institutions strengthened and cooperation increased between EIE, KOSGEB, TTGV and OIZs

actual.comment:
3) For introducing and promoting energy Management System (EnMS), several training sessions were held in different locations of Turkey. Industry managers, OIZ personnel, engineers, university professors, energy consultants and certification company employees participated in the trainings. The places, number of participants and the types of the trainings, which were held during the PIR period (including May and June 2014), are summarized below:
User Level:
Istanbul-1: 26
Istanbul-2: 27
Ankara-1: 23
Ankara-2: 41
Gaziantep: 23
Kayseri: 16
Izmir: 58
Bursa: 44
Denizli: 63
Adana: 29
Konya: 53
Training of Trainers:
Istanbul: 38
Ankara: 28
In summary, approximately 400 people were trained.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

baseline.comment: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs

target.comment:
New provisions available (EnMS)
Institutions strengthened and cooperation increased between EIE, KOSGEB, TTGV and OIZs

actual.comment:
4) Establishing and developing Energy Management Units (EMUs) in the OIZs is of crucial importance as these units will contribute to industrial companies within the borders of industrial zones to create awareness, to enhance the capacity, to promote energy audits, and to propose simple measures for investment. The milestones for this activity are summarized below:
4.a) In July 2014 an invitation letter together with a questionnaire were prepared and sent to 103 OIZs. Even though there are 272 OIZ licenses were authorized, some of them are not active as of now. Some of those who are active do not have more than 50 companies operating in the boundary. Even though Turkish legislation mandates to establish EMUs in OIZs whose total number of companies exceed 50, all eligible OIZs were invited to gather as much data as possible.
4.b) In September 2014 the applications were classified and analyzed. In October 2014, by the participation of the project partners, 9 OIZs were initially selected. It was decided to visit all selected OIZs to see their potential and availability to implement the program.
4.c) In November and December 2014 all 9 OIZs were visited. They were informed about the IEEI project, the data they submitted were checked, their physical facilities and human resources were examined.
4.d) In the final evaluation undertaken in January 2015, 3 of the initially selected OIZs were eliminated due to their insufficient capacity.
4.e) In February 2015, an official letter was sent to the remaining 6 OIZs. In the letter, the OIZs were requested to sign the commitment form to undertake the joint program. They all committed to cooperate and dedicate necessary resources.
4.f) In April 2015, a tender was announced by UNIDO for purchasing a set of basic equipment for the OIZs: an infrared camera (together with software for reporting), infrared temperature meter, ultrasonic liquid meter, energy analyzer (including data logger, cable, connector, clamps, and a suitable evaluation software), multifunction HVAC and indoor air quality meter (together with probes), flue gas analyzer, ultrasonic leak detector, tachometer, and water conductivity meter. The bid collection ended in May 2015. The evaluation still continues. Just after the procurement of the measuring devices, the program will be accelerated.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced capacity and awareness of Turkish industry and energy service providers

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: D) Additional number of EE projects investment made by industrial companies per year

baseline.comment: N/A

target.comment: About 200 EE investment directly (demos) or indirectly (outcome 2; capacity building)

actual.comment: The studies for increasing the number of investments in industrial EE are ongoing. The actual data will be gathered next year.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: E) Expanded business opportunities for ESCOs

baseline.comment: No performance contracts concluded by ESCOs to date

target.comment: At least 10 new performance contracts concluded by ESCOs per year

actual.comment: Removing this indicator was suggested in Midterm Review (Evaluation) Report, and accordingly the issue was drawn to the attention of 2014 PSC (project steering committee) meeting. In the 2014 PSC meeting, this suggestion was rejected. However, the PMU insisted that this indicator should be removed from the Project. In 2015 PSC meeting the issue was discussed again and removal proposal was approved by the committee. In the new project design, it is not an indicator any more.

target.comment: Improving the awareness level of energy efficiency in relevant parties.

actual.comment: 1) Awareness raising meetings were integrated with EnMS trainings. Beginning in September 2015, expert level training will be held for selected industrial companies. To determine these companies, an official invitation letter was sent to 145 prominent industrial plants, which were engaged in user level trainings, to join the program. The applications are still taken.

target.comment: Upgrading of intranet and extranet web portals

actual.comment:
2) The project web page was activated. Compilation of case studies for enriching the web page is underway.
3) A set of EE tips for SMEs were prepared. After acceptance by KOSGEB, they will be transformed into leaflets and circulated to the SMEs. For the beginning, 10 different topics were determined and elaborated. It is planned to increase the number of leaflets according to the feedback of the SMEs. The tips will also be distributed through participating OIZs.
4) Upgrading the Intranet and extranet EE web portals of YEGM and KOSGEB will commence after the completion of the Database Management task, which is, in effect, the prerequisite of this activity.
5) A huge translation and editing activity is ongoing. The aim is to submit technical training materials to YEGM, which will later train industrial facilities, ESCOs, universities, and chambers. Up to now 354 pages of Word document and 757 pages of PowerPoint document were finalized in “pumps” package. Currently, the translation of the “fans” package is underway. It is expected to submit more than 1000 pages material in July 2015. Then the materials for compressed air, steam and electrical motors will be handled.
6) The “Practical Guide for EnMS” prepared by UNIDO was translated into Turkish and 5000 copies were printed. It was (and will be) used as a training material in EE activities. It was circulated to the relevant industrial facilities, associations, ESCOs and financial institutions.
7) For review of ESCO experience and conducting a gap analysis, it was planned to recruit an international consultant. For this aim, the ToR has recently been drafted and submitted to NPD for his approval. It is expected to be announced in July 2015.
8) For enhancing the capacity of ESCOs (they are called EVD companies in the relevant legislation), a 3-day training course was carried in November 2014. The dishwasher factory of one of Turkey’s prominent manufacturers, Arcelik, was visited and audited by the participation of the representatives of 9 EVD companies, which were certified by YEGM to undertake energy audits. The actual implementation was later discussed and the results as well as approaches were criticized by the international consultants.
9) The study for producing 10 short training films (steam traps, compressed air, pumps, fans, boilers, furnaces, refrigeration systems, lighting systems, drying systems, insulation) and one generic film on EE in industry (through introducing the training center of YEGM) with English subtitles has been initiated. The contractor is currently working on designing the scenarios. The video shooting process is planned to begin in July 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Energy audit program for large industry and SMEs implemented

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: F) Share of energy audits in Turkey leading to actual investments in EE in industry

baseline.comment: Less than 10% (to be verified and adjusted within 1st project year)

target.comment: At least 50%

actual.comment:
1) An audit checklist (including around 80 questions about boilers, pumps, compressed air, etc.), prepared by project consultants, was finalized by the contribution of the YEGM experts, who had considerable experience in undertaking energy audits in the field. The checklist is ready to use for walk through energy audits, particularly in the utilities and general systems of the factories. The checklist was used during the training of the ESCOs (EVD companies) and the audit of the Arcelik plant.
2) The checklist will be supplemented by more detailed material for certain energy-intensive processes, especially in iron steel, cement, ceramics, paper and pulp, and chemicals industries. To find a competent company having experts in these fields, an RFP was prepared and submitted to the NPD for his approval in April 2015. The tender is expected to be announced in August 2015.
3) Within the context of the developing of an audit methodology, the EE auditing guide (including audit report template, basic principles, etc.) was developed and modified according to ISO 50002, which was issued in June 2014.
4) Energy Audits: The pilot phase of the energy audit activities was started in February 2015. Nine industrial facilities out of 51, which had previously been invited by GDRE officially, applied to be a part of the auditing program. Necessary background information of participating industrial companies for the bidding process such as energy consumption, production processes, the capacity of electricity transformers, features of steam systems, number of compressors, motors, etc. was collected by YEGM and the bidding process was initiated in January 2015. Seven eligible EVD companies were invited to bid. Six of them submitted their proposals on time. The contracting was finalized in February 2015 and the pre-audits (walk through energy audits (WTEAs)) were realized in March 2015. The WTEA reports were collected in April 2015. In May 2015, the evaluation committee held a 2 day meeting to assess the 9 reports. Letters providing the feedback from the evaluation committee were sent to the EVD companies. The EVD companies revised the reports and submitted the modified versions in June 2015. They were all re-evaluated and accepted. The EVD companies are now undertaking detailed energy audits. After the evaluation of the detailed energy audit reports, the new audit program will be designed in the light of lessons learned.
5) For further audits there will be a call for proposal including feasibility study supports. In this call for proposal the industrial companies will be invited to join the program for i) audits, ii) feasibility studies by committing that they will produce “investment projects”, which will also later be supported by the YEGM. The preparations studies are ongoing for this program.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: G) Additional energy saving investment opportunities identified as part of energy audits

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least 190 GWh/year in new EE investments identified

actual.comment: After the finalization of the pilot audit program, the potential for investments will be clarified. With further audits, more opportunities will arise for energy saving. Direct contribution to the feasibility studies of the investment projects will also be provided throughout the call for proposal.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: G) Additional energy saving investment opportunities identified as part of energy audits

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least 190 GWh/year in new EE Investments identified

location.name: Ankara
location.activity-description: To reduce energy consumption and associated GHG emissions in public buildings in Turkey by raising building energy performance standards, improving enforcement of building codes, enhancing building energy management and introducing the use of integrated building design approach.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Average thermal energy consumption in new buildings compared to baseline. 2. Cumulative CO2 emission reductions from new buildings to be built during project lifetime (2010-2015) against the baseline. 3. The content and status of new policies, programs, and implementers supporting implementation of EE and RE in buildings. 4. Implementation of demo constructions with IBDA resulting in significant energy improvements. 5. Required data, verification processes, and website utilization and relevance to key stakeholders. 6. The status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability .

baseline.comment: In 2000, there were 7.8 million buildings in the country and the total heating area was approximately 900-1,000 million m2. Between the 2000 census and 2008, an additional 750,000 buildings received construction permits , thus bringing the total number of buildings to 8.6 million, bringing the total floor area to approximately 1.7 billion m2, not including unregistered or informal construction. According to TUIK Building Census 2000 and Annual Building Statistics on construction permits 2000-2006, the share of residential buildings stood 86%, while the remaining 14% covered non-residential buildings, including public buildings like schools and government buildings. . Turkey's annual electricity demand has tripled since 1990, reaching 198 TWh in 2008. Electricity use in the residential sector stands at 40 TWh and commercial sector at 23 TWh. Though, the largest share of the building sector’s energy consumption (70% of the total energy mix) belongs to heating and hot water needs, which are met through natural gas, coal, wood and oil.

target.comment: 1.All the projects and tender dossiers for construction works for 5 demo buildings completed 2.The construction works for 5 demo buildings tendered and the construction works initiated 3.A checklist and a comprehensive guideline for “Strengthening the capacity of building inspectorates in regard to energy efficiency regulations” completed and regional trainings given 4.An online version of the training programme produced 5. ToR for MBEPs and nZEB prepared. 6. Energy Performance Certificates and Life Cycle Cost Analysis Reports for the demo buildings produced. 7.A team of 15 experts for promotion of IBDA through preparation of an "Adaptation Report" and an "Implementation Guidebook" established. 8. RFP for RET-EAT prepared and tendered.

actual.comment: 1.Design projects and tendering documents for five demo buildings were completed. 2.The construction works for 5 demo buildings tendered and the construction works were initiated. 3.A checklist and a comprehensive guideline for “Strengthening the capacity of building inspectorates in regard to energy efficiency regulations” were completed and regional trainings were given 4.An online version of the training programme was produced 5. ToR for MBEPs and nZEB was prepared. 6. Energy Performance Certificates and Life Cycle Cost Analysis Reports for the demo buildings were produced. 7.A team of 15 experts for promotion of IBDA through preparation of an "Adaptation Report" and an "Implementation Guidebook" was developed 8. RFP for RET-EAT was prepared and tendered.

target.comment: 1. Provision of Services for Renewable Energy Technologies- Economic Analysis Tool tendered 2. Provision of Services for Minimum Building Energy Performance Standards and Neraly Zero Energy Building Approach for Turkey tendered 3. Monitoring of Demo Buildings' Construction 4. Integrated Building Design Approach Adaptation Report and Implemantation Guidebook completed and published 5. Trainings for IBDA organized 6. "Modernising Codes on Building Energy Efficiency" book translated into Turkish 7. Training Materials for Instructors developed 8. Demonstration of renewable energy technologies and demo buildings in the training center in GDRE for buildings developed and organized

actual.comment: 1. Provision of Services for Renewable Energy Technologies- Economic Analysis Tool was tendered and the works initiated and ongoing. 2. RFP for Provision of Services for Minimum Building Energy Performance Standards and Neraly Zero Energy Building Approach for Turkey prepared and will be tendered on October. (ongoing) 3. Monitoring of Demo Buildings' Constructions are ongoing. 4. Integrated Building Design Approach Adaptation Report and Implemantation Guidebook completed and will be published (editing works ongoing) 5. "Modernising Codes on Building Energy Efficiency" book translated into Turkish and disseminated 6. Discussions on Training Materials for Instructors are ongoing 7. Demonstration of renewable energy technologies and demo buildings in the training center in GDRE for buildings are being developed.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To reduce energy consumption and associated GHG emissions in buildings in Turkey by raising building energy performance standards, improving enforcement of building codes, enhancing building energy management and introducing the use of an integrated building design approach

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Average total energy consumption (for heating, cooling, ventilation and lighting) in new residential and non-residential buildings

baseline.comment:
Residential: 200 kWh/m ²/year
Non-residential: 321 kWh/m ²/year

target.comment: Non-residential: 193 kWh/m ²/year for buildings built with IBDA

actual.comment:
A total of five buildings designed according to the Integrated Building Design Approach were simulated for building energy performances. The results achieved were far behind the targets. For the Sincan-Etimesgut Departments of Land Registry and Cadastre Office Building, 37.32kWh/m2/yr were achieved whereas for Cezeri Green Technologies High School the result was 23.62 kWh/m2/yr. The construction of the buildings were started and the total energy consumptions will be measured.
Moreover, to achive this objective, a Terms of Reference were prepared for developing New Minimum Building Energy Performance Standard (MBEPS) and Nearly Zero Energy Building (nZEB) Approach for Turkey.
In order to increase the awareness regarding the building codes in Turkey, a book, prepared by IEA and UNDP, was translated to Turkish.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Cumulative CO2 emission reductions from new buildings to be built during project lifetime (2010-2015) against the baseline

baseline.comment: 0 tCO2

target.comment: 2 million tCO2

actual.comment:
Within the scope of the project, 5 different buildings were designed using the Integrated Building Design Approach (IBDA). These buildings consist of 1 office building for Ministry of Environment and Urbanism and 4 buildings (school, workshop, dormitory, sports hall) for the Ministry of National Education. Tender documents were prepared for both Ministries and tendering procedures were completed by the Ministry of Environment and Urbanism in December 2014 and construction works are ongoing. Tendering procedures were completed by the Ministry of National Education in January 2015 and construction works are also ongoing. The total project direct emission reductions resulting from the construction of 5 demonstration buildings (around 30,000 m2 construction area) are estimated to be around 29,705 tCO2eq over a 20-year period. In order to reach the 2m tCO2eq emission reduction target, design and construction of 67 buildings following the IBDA approach will be adequate. This is easily achievable provided that the use of IBDA for new public buildings is adopted by the Government of Turkey.
The Ministry of Environment and Urbanism is highly interested in adaptation and implementation of IBDA and thereby its integration to the building by-laws. 3 books were pepared for the adaptation and implementation of IBDA in Turkey by 15 experts and the final editing works are ongoing. Complementary trainings on the use of IBDA and partnerships with selected universities for promoting IBDA are planned. Later, a strategy will also be developed to make IBDA mandatory for new public buildings.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Cumulative CO2 emission reductions from new buildings to be built during project lifetime (2010-2015) againist the baseline

baseline.comment: 0 tCO2

target.comment: 2 million tCO2

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Improved energy efficiency in new and existing buildings through stronger regulations, institutions and implementers

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The content and status of new policies, programs, and implementers supporting implementation of EE and RE in buildings

baseline.comment: Legislation, institutions, and implementers to support enhancement of building energy efficiency needs to be strengthened

target.comment: New legal and regulatory provisions, strengthened institutions, and better supporting compliance checking, enforcement and outreach programs adopted for enhanced EE in new buildings

actual.comment:
Once the “Energy Efficiency in New Buildings Checklist and Guidebook” document was completed, 4 regional training sessions were organized and completed in June 2014 in order to promote energy efficiency in new buildings. More than 600 participants were attended and to increase the number of people to reach the document and the trainings, an online training module was developed and uploaded to the website of the Ministry of Environment and Urbanism under Building Inspection System (www.yds.gov.tr). The Ministry is currently working on the checklist to integrate into the legislation. Once this checklist is integrated into "Building Inspection legislation”, it will be mandatory to apply the checklist for all new private building project designs and consecutively in constructions. This is more or less equal to 100.000 new buildings every year.
A new RFP document was prepared and will be launched in July 2015, for the development of Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) for new buildings and adaptation of Near Zero Energy Buildings (nZEB) for Turkey and energy efficiency strategy document for buildings.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Cost-effective energy efficiency solutions showcased through integrated building design approach application in two demo buildings

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Adoption and diffusion level of IBDA
Implementation of IBDA demonstration constructions

baseline.comment: Limited knowledge and application of IBDA

target.comment:
Cost effective energy efficiency solutions are demonstrated through IBDA demonstration buildings
IBDA is promoted through trainings and awareness raising activities

actual.comment:
For the 5 different demo buildings, the designs were completed and approved by the respective Ministries (Ministry of Environment and Urbanization for the office building and Ministry of National Education for school buildings (school, atelier workshop, dormitory and sports hall)). The tendering procedures were completed and the construction works have been initialized by the Ministry of Environment and Urbanization for the office building in December 2014. For the school buildings, the tendering procedures were completed and the construction works have been initialized by the Ministry of National Education in January 2015. Monitoring and Consultancy services in order to provide correct implementation of the project design are ongoing. Several visits to the construction site have been accomplished and the construction is closely followed up.
Energy Performance Certificates (A level Energy Performance Certificates for all buildings) from the BEP-TR program (a public issued building energy performance software) were received and Life Cycle Cost Analysis Reports for the demo buildings were produced. The simulated energy performances for office building and for school buildings are 37 kWh/m2/yr and 23 kWh/m2/yr respectively.
Life Cycle Cost Analysis Reports for the demo buildings were prepared according to the approximate cost values and the payback period for the office building was found to be around 6 years and the payback period for the school buildings was found to be around 13 years. When the life cycle cost analysis were repeated with the actual costs of the buildings accoring to the bid amounts, the payback period for the office building was found to be around 4.5 years.
A team of 15 experts for promotion of IBDA through preparation of an "Adaptation Report" and an "Implementation Guidebook" was established. The team has produced 3 books with an addition of “Priorities and Targets for the Building Performance” book. All the books are reviewed several times by the experts of the Ministries and comments were received. Editing works are ongoing and printing versions are being prepared for all the three books.
Complimentary training activities and cooperation with selected universities are also planned for October 2015. The real impact of this outcome is directly related to the adoption level of IBDA by the Government. The performance levels of IBDA demonstration buildings are impressive. The user behavior and its effect on performance are yet to be seen following the completion of demonstration buildings. The performance will be monitored when the operation phase starts.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: New tools developed and introduced to facilitate compliance with higher energy efficiency standards and application of integrated building design approach in buildings

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Monitoring and verification processes are in place and disseminated effectively among key stakeholders

baseline.comment:
No monitoring system for building energy performance
No analysis tool for RE in new buildings
Training materials need significant upgrading

target.comment:
New tools are developed for analysis and monitoring purposes, financial mechanisms
Training materials revised/developed
Existing websites and tools updated

actual.comment:
A tender document was prepared in order to develop an economic analysis (feasibility) tool for the use of renewable energy technologies (RET-EAT) during the design of new buildings. The tender was carried out, however due to budget constraints, the tender was cancelled in July 2014. Revisions were made in the RFP and the tendering process was repeated in January 2015. Seven bids were received and the contract was signed in May 2015 with the successful tenderer. The kick-off meeting were organized in June 2015 and the activity is ongoing.
For the development/revision of the training materials on energy management and energy auditing for buildings, communications and assessments with the legal entities and the ministry are ongoing. The requirements were listed and possible ways to have them prepared are being searched.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Building energy consumption, energy savings, and other results of the project monitored, evaluated, and reported

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability

baseline.comment: Insufficient institutional mechanisms in place to ensure sustainability of project results

target.comment: Project recommendations to ensure institutional sustainability adopted

actual.comment:
In order to contribute to the institutional stability in terms of building energy performance, developing New Minimum Building Energy Performance Standard (MBEPS) for Turkey, and Developing Near-Zero-Energy Building (nZEB) Approach for Turkey is an important step and is ongoing. Several trainings were accomplished and new trainings are being planned.
Besides, a communications strategy for effective dissemination of project results and improved awareness raising activities is also developed.
A launching meeting is being organized for the demo buildings.
New brochures for the integrated design approach key issues has been prepared and published. Ministry of Environment and Urbanism distributed the brochures (approximately #5000) in their service trainings and will go on sharing the brochures prepared by our project.

baseline.comment: Area of forest landscapes in Turkey with integrated forest- plans developed and under implementation that deliver multiple environmental benefits (biodiversity, climate change), 0 ha.

target.comment: • Training module for LULUCF Unit and local foresters prepared. • Roadmap for revision on legal framework prepared. • MRV concept and scope identified. • Roadmap for NAMA is prepared. • Integrated fire management approach under preparation. • Training tools are under preparation for carbon focused silvicultural activities. • Site specific silviculture plans under preparation. • IPM system under preparation. Data forms and site specific activities identified. • Roadmap for identification of carbon protocols and MRV system within forest management plans under preparation. • Biodiversity assessment of 2 pilot sites under implementation. • Species specific ecological surveys under implementation.

actual.comment: *Training module for LULUCF Unit and local foresters prepared; content and materials for the training module are prepared, a review is ongoing. •Roadmap for revision on legal framework prepared; Forest Protection Department at the GDF is identified as the key department with specific roles with legislation to be amended. •MRV concept and scope identified; MRV system will be piloted at Mediterranean region to be up-scaled at national scale at the end of the project. •Roadmap for NAMA is prepared; Foreign Relations Department is identified as the key department at GDF and consultations started with Min.of Environment •Integrated fire management approach under preparation; strategy for fire management is two folded, i.e fuel management and preparedness •Training tools are under preparation for carbon focused silvicultural activities; a need assessment at pilot sites prepared for silviculture activities •Site specific silviculture plans under preparation; size and number of units for experiment pilots are identified. •IPM system under preparation. Data forms and site specific activities identified; site base pest problems and capacity needs are identied. •Roadmap for identification of carbon protocols and MRV system within forest management plans under preparation; forest management plans are assessed to analyze how to integrate carbon protocols in the ENVANIS database •Biodiversity assessment of 4 pilot sites under implementation; 4 pilot sites are started with field surveys for 5 different taxa, and one other site is started with field surveys for 3 different taxa •Species specific ecological surveys under implementation; 5 pilot sites are prepared with maps and inventories for ecological surveys.

target.comment: *Hands on training for LULUCF Unit and local foresters under implementation. •MRV methodology identified specifically for forestry sector •Integrated fire management plans for pilot sites prepared. *Equipment and supplies for integrated fire management system are purchased. •Training modules for carbon focused silvicultural activities specific to pilot sites under preparation. •Experimental site plots for carbon focused silviculture plans are identified. •Labs for IPM system established. •Roadmap for identification of carbon protocols and MRV system within forest management plans are prepared. •Biodiversity assessment of 5 pilot sites finalized. •Species specific ecological surveys finalized. *Communication strategy and plan prepared. *Communication and training kit for integrated forest management with printed materials and short films are finalized.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To promote an integrated approach to management of forests in Turkey, demonstrating multiple environmental benefits in high conservation value forests in the Mediterranean forest region

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Area of forest landscapes in Turkey with integrated forest- plans developed and under implementation that deliver multiple environmental benefits (biodiversity, climate change), ha.

target.comment: 0.45 mln ha

actual.comment: Project initiated several activities at site level and headquarter level to enable the legislative and organisational structure for ensuring integration at landscape level. While the target level at end of the project (i.e. 0.45 mln ha) will be achieved through cumulative effect of all progress at each outcomes, current contribution of outcomes is promising with several facts as following; (i) LULUCF unit established and MRV action plan prepared (ii) Process for amending legislation and site based activities are in line for producing technical and policy level justifications, (iii) site based interventions for mitigation activities (i.e. fire and pest management, solar water heating systems), and enhancement of carbon stocks (silvicultural activities) are detailed in an integrated approach at 1/25.000 maps, (iv) rapid biodiversity assessment at all pilot sites started (some taxa already mapped) along with silvicultural implementation plans.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Policy and institutional framework for integrated forest management within landscape

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: LULUCF Unit

baseline.comment: No properly capacitated LULUCF Unit in the Government

target.comment: One adequately staffed and funded LULUCF unit with technical capacities to drive forest carbon efforts forward in the country

actual.comment: One adequately staffed and funded LULUCF unit established. Capacity needs assessment is under implementation. List of names, roles and responsibilities, and organisational structure are modified according to project needs. LULUCF Unit already started their works on INDC, calculation of LULUCF sector and other related works in according to the requests from the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation, and Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Role of LULUCF Unit on forest based MRV and NAMA identified. Upon capacity enhancement activities, LULUCF Unit will lead the MRV and NAMA related activities.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Forest protected area regulatory framework

baseline.comment: No legal framework defining forest PA expansion and integration within broader landscape

target.comment: Effective regulatory framework enables GDF to establish forest PAs based on combined SFM criteria, including biodiversity and carbon

actual.comment: The GDF and related departments identified needs and process for amending regulation on forest PAs. Required data from Component 3 identified to understand the scale and scope of the amendment in the Protected Forests Regulation. It is decided to start the legislative works upon justification of biodiversity conservation needs for permanency and integrity through field surveys in the Pilot sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: MRV for forest-based mitigation and sequestration

baseline.comment: No MRV

target.comment: One MRV for forest-based mitigation and sequestration in Turkey is developed, with initial emphasis on Mediterranean region.

actual.comment: A detailed activity plan to deploy MRV for forest-based mitigation and sequestration prepared by the project team, and endorsed by the GDF. LULUCF Unit, academia, and Forest Information System coordinator within GDF have been consulted along with the GoldStandard Foundation. A project cooperation agreement was drafted to undertake activities to prepare MRV starting in the second half of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Forest sector Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action (NAMA)

baseline.comment: No NAMA

target.comment: One fully developed NAMA covering 2-4 million ha Mediterranean-region forests

actual.comment: The Steering Committee and the LULUCF Unit was consulted on the NAMA issue since the position of Turkey on eligibility is under question. As a result of the Steering Committee decision, it was decided to undertake consultation with the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation, the Focal Point of the UNFCCC, to elaborate Turkey's position on NAMA. According to the advise from the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation, it was decided to wait for official communication from the Secretariat of UNFCCC. Once the official communication will be finalised, the MoEU will share the decision with the Steering Committee and the LULUCF Unit of the GDF.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Implementation of forest-based GHG mitigation and carbon sequestration tools within landscape

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Fire management and carbon losses from fires

baseline.comment: Suppression-focused fire management system; annual carbon losses at five pilot sites average 3,629 tCO2/y

target.comment: Proactive (prevention and load management focussed) fire management methods at pilot sites generate carbon benefits of 1,646 tCO2/y over baseline.

actual.comment: Site based interventions, forest unit based mitigation options, fuel management strategies are elaborated with the Department of Fire Combating, and academia. A detailed plan for integrated fire management system, a list of required equipment, software, and training needs drafted. Terms of Reference for national consultant prepared and an Integrated Fire Management consultant hired. Yearly intervention plans at all pilot sites are under preparation.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Silvicultural methods consider carbon and biodiversity aspects. Assessment of associated carbon benefits.

baseline.comment: Carbon benefits not taken into account or measured; locations not chosen to maximize connectivity enhancements.

target.comment: Silvicultural approaches at pilot sites generate carbon benefits of 11,572 tCO2/y along with enhanced connectivity.

actual.comment: Locations chosen to maximize connectivity enhancements. As a result of field surveys, a site of 3,919 ha was identified to undertake silvicultural efforts for carbon and biodiversity aspects in 2015. A carbon-focused silviculture consultant and a afforestation consultant were hired. A detailed plan for carbon focused silviculture and afforestation action plan at site level with capacity of carbon stocks were prepared. Activity plan at site level and forest unit level are under preparation.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Fuel wood removals and associated carbon fluxes.

baseline.comment: High levels of legal and illegal fuel wood removals for household consumption, especially home heating, with resulting annual carbon losses at five pilot sites averaging 18,775 tCO2/y. No alterative system to replace fire wood consumption in place.

target.comment: Expansion of micro-credit program into Mediterranean region generates carbon benefits of 13,038 tCO2/y over baseline

actual.comment: As per the Steering Committee meeting decision and technical workshops with related GDF departments, ORKOY's micro-credit programme will started after a detailed study on socio-economic situation of forest villages within pilot sites and a technology assessment for house heating solar systems including solar water heating system are complete. Terms of Reference for both services prepared and submitted to the GDF.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Integrated pest management (IPM) and associated carbon fluxes

baseline.comment: No proactive IPM, resulting annual carbon losses at five pilot sites averaging 45,286 tCO2/y.

target.comment: Introduction of IPM methods and establishment of two pest centres generates carbon benefits of 30,191 tCO2/y over baseline.

actual.comment: Location of two pest centres identified. Required activities for equipping and running of pest centres with laboratories and early warning system are in progress. Site based interventions, pest-specific action plans, data management of integrated pest management strategy are elaborated with the Department of Pest Management. A list of required equipment, and training needs drafted. A national Integrated Pest Management Consultant was hired. Yearly intervention plans at all pilot sites are under preparation.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Carbon protocols designed and completed before, during and after implementation of enhancement and mitigation efforts

baseline.comment: No carbon protocol

target.comment: Introduction of carbon protocols in line with MRV system (Output 1.3) enabling integration of climate change into forest management plans through a central LULUCF Database under Forest Information System (FIS) Project of GDF.

actual.comment: Terms of reference for a national consultant on forest management plans, and a national consultant on carbon protocols are prepared and submitted to the GDF. Upon technical inputs from the related departments, the consultants will be hired. ENVANIS system to be upgraded for carbon protocols has been elaborated through several technical workshops and meetings with the Forest Management and Planning Department of the GDF. 1/25.000 scale maps of all pilot sites with current forest management functions prepared, overlapped with biodiversity data, along with fire, pest, silviculture, afforestation action plans. A process for ecosystem base multi-functional planning with specific table and optimal situation for climate change and biodiversity was drafted.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Strengthening protection of high conservation value forests in Mediterranean landscape

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Extent of forest PAs

baseline.comment: Mediterranean forest habitats are under-represented in national PA system

target.comment: Effective protection extended to 79,960 ha, including under-represented Mediterranean forest habitats.

actual.comment: Identification of 79,960 ha "Protected Forests" through rapid biodiversity assessment and integration into forest management plans of 5 sites started. Biodiversity rapid assessment for 6 taxa (large mammals, small mammals, birds, herpetofauna, butterflies, plants) and ecological assessment within all pilot sites under implementation with involvement of several academia, forest directorate officials at site level and biodiversity branch of the GDF. Identification of silvicultural activities in line with biodiversity targets underpinned by rapid assessment carried out in 5 pilot sites. Preparation of Forest Biodiversity strategy and action plan for GDF, including national and local capacity assessment studies have been elaborated with the GDF. Upon discussions, it was decided to undertake such activities on capacity assessment next year, upon obtaining results of the ongoing rapid assessment. Two books on biodiversity and forest management prepared and published for forest engineers at national and local level.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: PA management effectiveness: METT Score

baseline.comment:
Aladaglar National Parks - 35 METT Score
Kartal Lake Nature Reserve - 21 METT score

target.comment:
Aladaglar National Parks - 40 METT Score
Kartal Lake Nature Reserve - 40 METT score

actual.comment:
Aladaglar National Parks - 35 METT Score
Kartal Lake Nature Reserve - 21 METT Score
The updated scores will be available for the midterm review in 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Improvement in biodiversity indicator species at pilot sites

baseline.comment: See baseline values for pilot sites in table below

target.comment: See target values for pilot sites in table below

actual.comment: Field studies for all taxa started last year. As of 30 June 2015, consultants are in the field with the forestry officials for the surveys for large mammals, small mammals, birds, herpetofauna, butterflies, and plants. Habitat suitability assessment are also under implementation. 10 orchids identified while one is local endemic (Ophyrs amanensis subsp. antalyansis) in one pilot site. Distribution maps prepared and biodiversity friendly forestry activities drafted.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Carbon benefits from forest Pas

baseline.comment: Areas are subject to regular logging according to management plans, carbon pools diminishing.

target.comment: Net carbon benefit associated with new conservation areas estimated at 64,245 t CO2e/year.

actual.comment: Biodiversity rapid assessment is under implementation. Initial maps are produced according to biodiversity importance. Final maps with new protected forests will be ready in 2016. According to the final maps and biodiversity requirements, logging schemes will be revised with calculations on net carbon benefits in 2016. All calculations will be in line with MRV system to be developed under Outcome 1.
